title: Why didn't Ronnie Van Zant like Neil Young? - Quora

response.answer_text: Who says he didn't? Here's a photo of Ronnie. Can you tell who that is on his t-shirt? (Hint: it's Neil.)  Van Zant was a proud Southerner and a self-professed “hillbilly”, but he was not a bigot, nor were his bandmates. So when he heard Neil Young's songs “Southern Man” and “Alabama”, he judged them, rightly so, as condescending and presumptuous, painting all white Southerners as racists, and wrote “Sweet Home Alabama” — mainly as a joke, according to him — in response (despite Skynyrd being from Florida, not Alabama). In Van Zant's own words: “We thought Neil was shooting all the ducks in order to kill one or two. We’re Southern rebels, but more than that, we know the difference between right and wrong.” “Sweet Home Alabama” was meant to remind Neil Young that simply being white and from the South didn't make someone ignorant or bigoted. Young, for his part, loved the song, and himself admits that “Alabama” in particular “richly deserved the shot Lynyrd Skynyrd gave me with their great record. I don't like my words when I listen to it. They are accusatory and condescending, not fully thought out, and too easy to misconstrue.” So the real story is, Ronnie and the rest of Skynyrd were big fans of Young, Young was a big fan of Skynyrd, and Ronnie and Neil were actually friends. With “Sweet Home Alabama”, Ronnie was just taking a lighthearted shot at Neil for taking what he saw as an unfair shot at the South. Neil Young & Lynyrd Skynyrd: The Friendliest of Feuds

There was no feud between Neil and anyone with Lynyrd Skynyrd. They respected each other’s work immensely. After the brou haha over “Sweet Home Alabama” they met and actually became rather close. Neil and Ronnie both hated racism. The famous line “Southern man don’t need him around anyhow”, was not so much a Neil put down, but a notice that Southern men didn’t need help healing the racial divide. “We got this. We’re working on it”.
